Award.AwardTitle: DCL: HBCU Conference Proposal: A National Symposium to Build Research Capacity at Historically Black Colleges and Universities through Collaborations with STEM Advocates and Practi
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black College and University (HBCU) Research Action and Practice (RAP) Symposium will elevate research and institutional partnernships to advance STEM, and build collaborations with stakeholders, giving researchers at HBCUs greater leverage to contribute to national efforts that require STEM input. Though a small segment of our Nation's colleges, HBCUs disproportionately graduate African American STEM degree recipients. The conference's collaboration and dissemination strategies will catalyze HBCU researchers and stakeholders to support achievement of the Nation's goals of filling needed STEM expertise in the labor market and diversifying the STEM workforce. An expected outcome of the Symposium activities is an action plan that will share what works in building a community of practice between HBCU researchers and STEM stakeholders.

As the U.S. faces a shortage of experts to fill projected STEM workforce needs, Historically Black Colleges and Universities are prime institutions to seriously be considered as a source of STEM expertise, especially for students and researchers that have been traditionally under-involved in STEM. The HBCU Research Action and Practice (RAP) Symposium seeks to highlight the capacity of HBCUs to increasingly contribute to the scientific research enterprise. The objectives of the HBCU RAP Symposium is to build the research capacity of HBCUs through: 1) hosting a workshop to increase the collaborative energy between HBCU researchers, administrators and a cross-section of stakeholders, and increase awareness of NSF's 300 programs to HBCUs, 2) convening a research forum to elevate and translate research led by HBCUs in a setting that strategically positions it to advance STEM action and practice and 3) building a community of practice to cultivate relationships so that HBCU researchers, administrators, and STEM supporters will develop collaborations to advance STEM research at HBCUs eventually increasing institutional research capacity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RAP Symposium Overview: From 2018 to 2020, with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Award #1842726, the Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) Network conducted a symposium and national forum in conjunction with the 2018 Congressional Black Caucus Foundation's Annual Legislative Conference (ALC) to assist HBCUs with building their collective capacity for STEM-focused research and to inform the larger STEM community of stakeholders and practitioners about HBCU-led research initiatives. Participants at the two-day symposium comprised of two-person teams consisting of a Chief Research Officer/Sponsored Program Administrator and a leading STEM Faculty researcher (Principal Investigator for grant-funded projects). Fifty-eight (58) senior research officers, administrators, and faculty, representing teams from 29 HBCUs attended the symposium.

Symposium Evaluation Summary: At the end of the symposium, participants received evaluation questionnaires to solicit feedback regarding their overall experience at the symposium. Ninety percent of participants (52 out of 58) responded to the symposium evaluation questionnaire. An overwhelming majority of respondents agreed/strongly agreedthat the symposium increased their knowledge in the following areas:

  • 100% -importance of developing a community of practice to advance STEM research at HBCUs
  • 98% - national priorities in STEM research in education
  • 96% -critical elements for success and NSF funding opportunities, respectively
  • 95% - NSF's Research and Related Activities (R&RA) directorates
  • 94% -value of partnering with other HBCUs 

RAP Report: Following the 2018 symposium, QEM prepared and released a report, Let it Resound: Research, Action, and Practice for Historically Black Colleges and Universities that featured information from multiple sources including notes from round-table discussions, plenary sessions, panel sessions and feedback provided on the post-symposium survey. The report was released during the second RAP symposium that was held on September 12-14, 2019.

 

HBCU Mixtapes: Following the RAP Report release, QEM conducted interviews with nine HBCU researchers to highlight HBCU research and researchers to understand and address social and scientific issues in the nation. By the time of this reporting, the production of six videos had been completed and posted in multiple platforms including Facebook, LinkedIn, YouTube, Twitter, and websites (QEM and the NSF National INCLUDES Network). The videos have been watched over 2000 times. The videos were shared widely to the HBCU STEM community, other MSIs, and the broader public.

QEM works with minority and non-minority individuals, organizations, and institutions to help coordinate and energize efforts to improve the education of minorities, particularly in STEM
